## üîç Status
- You‚Äôve told me you love apple pie and it‚Äôs your favorite; I‚Äôve got that on record. [M1, M2]

## üçé Options
- Recipe: classic from-scratch, quick (store-bought crust), or gluten-free
- Smart shopping list: exact amounts by pie size, with brand tips
- Bake plan: timing, doneness checks, and storage/freezing tips
- Pairings: vanilla ice cream, sharp cheddar, spice tweaks
- Crust choices: all-butter vs. butter+shortening (pros/cons)

Want a classic, no-fail apple pie recipe now, or a quick version?

data.title: Quantum Information Panpsychism Explained | Federico Faggin
data.summary: Summary: The interview features inventor Federico Faggin, who argues that consciousness is fundamental and best described as a quantum-information field, with the body acting like a ‚Äúdrone‚Äù interface. Inspired by a profound 1990 experience, he moved from physicalism to a view where qualia are not in the brain but in a conscious field, and where each person is a field that is simultaneously observer, observed, and actor. He collaborates with physicist Giacomo Mauro D‚ÄôAriano, proposing that quantum physics can be derived from quantum information, framing inner experience as quantum information and wavefunction collapse as an expression of free will. Faggin critiques classical emergentism, emphasizes a part-whole ‚Äúholographic‚Äù nature of living systems, and warns against a purely mechanistic view that could enable AI-driven control. Key Points:
keyPoints: Federico Faggin (first microprocessor, touchpad, early neural nets) proposes a quantum-information-based theory of consciousness.
A 1990 Lake Tahoe experience led him to view consciousness as prior to matter, with spacetime arising within conscious fields.
He describes qualia as existing in a conscious field, not the brain; the body functions as a quantum-classical interface (‚Äúdrone‚Äù).
With Giacomo Mauro D‚ÄôAriano, he links quantum information to inner experience and interprets wavefunction collapse as free will.
He rejects classical emergentism, cites biological part-whole (genome, epigenetics) organization, and cautions that a mechanistic worldview risks human subjugation via AI.
data.whyMatters: If correct, this reframes both the mind-body problem and quantum mechanics‚Äô interpretation, suggesting consciousness is fundamental. It also informs ethical and societal debates on AI by challenging the notion that humans are merely machines.
